posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14489634
Just like North Korea, the Estado Novo produced:

A population completely closed off from the rest of the world information-wise, the government censored everything from letters to books to movies and radio broadcasts

A population obscenely dependent on subsistence farming considering they were part of Western Europe. A rural exodus to the main cities aggravated the situation, since people didn't have land to farm in the slums around the cities a small scale famine occured.

A tiny elite who oversaw the industry exploited the impoverished majority of the population, labor rights were few and even those that existed were not enforced effectively, as the factory owners were in league with the government officials.

A secret police that abducted, tortured and killed people who were suspected to be against the regime, pressured people into becoming informants and had near limitless power over the population inside and outside Portugal (a political opponent of Salazar's was assassinated in Spain by the PIDE)

The colonial war also lasted 13 years and mobilized 1 million men (most of them draftees), bled the country's massive gold reserves and made it impossible for any type of federalization or otherwise amicable solution that would benefit Portugal in the long run(a la France and West Africa).

The one credit I can give Salazar and the Estado Novo was the handling of WWII (remaining neutral and keeping Spain neutral, while profitting off both sides of the war) and the massive construction of roads (the country was notoriously behind in infrastructure, and some areas were incredibly remote and hard to reach by car, despite the small size of the country) and the construction of thousands of primary schools across the country, and making 4th grade education mandatory (although these were also places where state propaganda could be fed to the kids).

Are there any legitimate reasons for liberal governments to enforce laws prohibiting minors from engaging in consensual sexual activity with adults? All these laws manage to do is to stigmatize consensual sexual relations, fuel mass hysteria, and imprison innocent people.

Some claim that the existence of AOC laws prevents instances of child rape or other forms of sexual impropriety, but there is no empirical data supporting the claim that AOC laws lower the rates of or prevent child rape from occurring. For example, the Netherlands from 1989-2001 lowered their effective AOC to 12, and saw no increase in instances of sexual abuse involving minors, until reverting it to 16 under pressure from the United States.

It seems that antis operate under the presuppositions: (a) the majority of sexual relations between adults and minors are non-consensual, (b) minors are more likely to react negatively towards sex with adults, even though they may be willing participants, and (c) consensual sexual activity between an adult and a minor is likely to resolve in psychological harm for the minor.

But none of those premises are true. Sexual relations between adults and minors are not more likely to be non-consensual, people don't react more negatively to sexual activity according to a function of age, and there is absolutely no link between consensual sexual relationships and psychological harm.

Some claim that minors are incapable of consent for deontic reasons, therefore adult-minor sex is wrong irrespective of whether harm occurs, but all common forms of this argument ultimately rely on the condition that sexual activity between adults and minors are likely to result in harm, which is circular reasoning.

See Rind, B., Tromovitch, P. & Bauserman, R. (1998), Rind, B. (2022), Steever, E. E., Follette, V. M., & Naugle, A. E. (2001), and Constantine (1981).

The first thing they did after arriving in my area was steal cars and trucks - not for the war effort, but as gifts for their families back home in Germany. One officer spent several days going from farm to farm to find and 'confiscate' stallions for his stud farm, and when farmers complained he told them to not pursue the question any further 'or else'. German soldiers also emptied the stores of chocolate and coffee, because those had been difficult to get in Germany for months by that point. In houses where German soldiers were quartered, they stole everything of value (even things like baby clothes and small items of furniture) and broke everything else.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14486869
As the war dragged on and Germany began to face the prospect of defeat, the German soldiers went from being corrupt to being cruel. In order to prevent Allied gliders from landing in the area, they put up wooden poles in fields and ordered all civilian boys and men in the area to stand by and guard those poles throughout the night. Those who ignored their summons or left their poles during the night were beaten and robbed. Eventually, even old men and young boys had to guard those poles, because all the smart young men had already gone into hiding to avoid being 'drafted' for slave labor in Germany, and all the dumb young men had already been caught and put on a train to work under constant Allied bombing in the Ruhr.

The German soldiers also became increasingly paranoid about resistance groups and illegal radios, so they began to kick down the doors of houses, stores and even churches. If any 'contraband' was found in a house, the family living there would typically have its men and adolescent boys sent to concentration camps, where many of them died. When Germans or collaborators were killed by the resistance, the Germans would carry out retaliatory deportations or executions of civilians; in one case, in the village of Putten in October 1944, a German officer was ambushed by a resistance group, and the Germans then burned 105 houses and deported 601 men, of whom only 48 returned alive.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14486937
When the war ended it still wasn't quite over for civilians. When Germany surrendered in May 1945, the Allies still had several days of travel left in order to reach all corners of this country. On May 7, in Amsterdam's city center, civilians were celebrating Germany's surrender. However, the Allies had not yet reached Amsterdam, and in one of the buildings overlooking the square where the celebrations took place there were armed German soldiers (previously Kriegsmarine sailors, but put on garrison duty because the German navy had practically ceased to exist) who decided to open fire on the crowd, killing at least 32 people and injuring at least 100 more. Elsewhere in the city, a detachment of SS men stationed in a hotel also opened fire on civilians.

>>14480800
The oldest complete sea worthy boat ever discovered in the world comes form Europe. Italy, 5500 bc
One end protruded from the mud. It looked as if it could be the stern of a boat. What emerged from the mud, after several months of careful vacuuming in 1994, is the 35-foot-long dugout canoe that is now in the Pigorini. Three and a half feet across at the stern, tapering to two and a half at the bow, it was carved from a single massive oak trunk; along the rough and wavy floor, you can see the marks left by stone axes and adzes. (The Neolithic was the last period of the Stone Age, and metal tools didn't exist.) The boatwrights left four transverse stripes of oak, an inch or so high, at intervals along the floor. Those must have acted as ribs to strengthen and stabilize the canoe. Three trapezoidal blocks of wood with holes pierced in them were also found loose in the bottom of the canoe; they may have been used for fastening sails—though the only direct evidence are a few small fragments of fabric found nearby. "These people navigated up and down the Mediterranean," Fugazzola believes. "They knew about sails." They may also have fastened two canoes together to make a catamaran, she says, with a deck of planks. With or without sails, as a catamaran or a monohull, there is no doubt the settlers' canoe was seaworthy, not just lake-worthy. Several years ago, a team of Czech archaeologists led by Radomir Tichy built a copy of it, using replicas of Neolithic stone tools. They proceeded to sail their dugout nearly 500 miles along the Mediterranean coast, from Italy to Portugal. Head winds forced them ashore on occasion. High seas, Tichy recalls, once put them "in a complicated situation. All members remained in the boat, but water was in the boat too." Yet they arrived in Lisbon without serious mishap

Basically in Aristotle's framework dynamic motion required a constant acting force to drive an object (as opposed to the ability of objects to have relative motion/inertia without a force acting on it).

This involves connecting the integrated acceleration due to force with differential change in position/velocity. That's why the Fundmantal Theorem of Calculus (also by Newton/Leibniz) was so essential to the three laws of motion.

Everyone had a basic feeling that this is what it should be (throw an object and it keeps moving even though you don't apply force to it), but without a mathematical model like Newton's laws we could not move forward. Many people before him came with models involving integration and differentiation of infinitesimals etc., but making that connection is not as obvious if you weren't gifted it in a modern Calculus class.

>So what exactly could students of Newtonian physics do that students of the Greeks could not in real practical terms?
I don't how practical you consider it to be (it was to the Chruch), but the actual immediate application was to come up with laws of motion that correctly predicted the movement of planets and there was even a bounty on this. Keppler's law were emperical fits, people knew there had to be something more fundamental, but could not find it and Aristotle's laws failed to model it correctly. Of course, Europeans knew in the 500s AD already it was deeply flawed, but early proposals for fundamental laws to replace simply did not work either largely due to not having access to the FTC.

Similarly, for your example, artillery Sergeants could predict the motion of _their_ mortars and cannons from loads which they figured out through trial and error. Not from fundamental laws. What's the difference? Truly understanding the underlying phenomena allows you to design and optimize a cannon and predict the trajectory of your projectiles before you ever build it nevermind fire the first shot. Engineering is an art, and Newton's laws are one of its most valuable tool even to this day.

Now the reason it is a breakthrough is not because of that, but because of what followed. The laws of _dynamic_ (as opposed to static) fluids (Navier-Stokes), Cauchy stress, electromagnetism (Maxwell) etc. all rely on Newton's (mathematically modelled) concept of momentum. These equations in turn underly nearly all the rapid industrial advancements we made. Arguably only Gauss, Gibbs and Helmoltz contributed more to the modern Chemical Engineering and materials industry. Dynamic industrial controllers, planes, rockets etc. are all impossible to design without these advancements.

Cont.

>muh habeas corpus
It was a fucking war. A Civil War with Southern sympathizers hidden like little rats throughout the Union. As close as the Buchanan administration treacherous Southerners in the cabinet were sending intelligence to the Confederacy before the war. Working against the Union even came in the form of a woman before Gettysburg passing on the positions of union troops around a town to a Confederate general hidden under flowers. When the existence of the Union itself is in peril you cannot take chances. Both the Congress of the Union and Confederacy were more than willing to give the power to suspend habeas corpus. Lincoln himself never ordered any random man's arrest, power to do that was designated to military officers and to an extent Seward. This had to happen because they were the ones actually on the situation and Lincoln probably in a literal sense would not have had enough time to take on that burden himself in any remotely efficient manner. Any abuse of their individual power cannot be attributed directly to Lincoln, unless habeas corpus was not necessary to suspend in the first place (it was) or a radically different system of bringing the disloyal to justice should and could have been implemented. When Lincoln DID exercise his powers in cases concerning arrests he leaned toward leniency, like that time he told one of his generals (I can't remember which, Burnside?) to unsuspend a newspaper and warned against suspending again without better reason, or the time he intervened for a reverend to not be jailed.
>but muh suspension without Congress
Congress wasn't in session and he needed to take action quickly. Marylanders were tearing up the railroads to D.C. and thereby threatening the capital as federal troops couldn't get there. While unlikely in retrospect an imminent invasion of Washington was widely feared and troops greatly needed to combat any potential threat, lest the capital be taken.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14489553
(cont).
Lincoln could not afford to wait for Congress to travel and convene in order to allow him to do something everyone knew they would quickly allow him to do. Furthermore the suspension of the writ of habeas corpus is not explicitly said to be the power of Congress in the Constitution. It is implied it is by being in Article 1, but it's just slapped there unlike the other powers without being designated to Congress. In fact the wording doesn't specifically even give the power to anyone, it just says it restricts the power to suspend it to cases of rebellion or invasion when the public safety requires it. It is arguable that the men at the Constitutional Convention believed that it made sense to allow room for the president to suspend habeas corpus, since in situations requiring a decision to be made as soon as humanly possible when national security is threatened Congress may not even be in session, dispersed in their homes throughout the country. Lincoln was using an untraditional interpretation but he had to do this in order to protect the Constitution in the first place.
>ex parte Merryman
Taney was a single Supreme Court justice making that ruling. It was not actual judicial review or binding on the president.
>arrest of Vallandigham

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hadith_terminology#Terminology_relating_to_the_authenticity_of_a_hadith

>Sahih (Arabic: صحيح, Ṣaḥīḥ) may be translated as "authentic" or "sound". Ibn Hajar defines a hadith that is ṣaḥīḥ lidhātihi ("ṣaḥīḥ in and of itself") as a singular narration (ahaad; see below) conveyed by a trustworthy, completely competent person, either in his ability to memorize or to preserve what he wrote, with a muttaṣil ("connected") isnād ("chain of narration") that contains neither a serious concealed flaw (ʻillah, Arabic:علة) nor irregularity (shādhdh).

>Da‘if (ضعيف, Ḍaʻīf) is the categorization of a hadith as "weak". Ibn Hajar described the cause of a hadith being classified as weak as "either due to discontinuity in the chain of narrators or due to some criticism of a narrator." This discontinuity refers to the omission of a narrator occurring at different positions within the isnād and is referred to using specific terminology accordingly as discussed below.

>>14488919
>Why can’t a new pagan religion be made?
Because it wouldn't be "pagan" in the sense of pre-Christian European religions, which were really just a series of rituals that had to be done in very specific ways perfectly otherwise they'd actually bring misfortune to the practitioner. That's the essence of paganism - the ritual, not belief in the supernatural. It didn't matter what a person believed as long as they performed the proper rites. Seeing as there's no way to properly do these rituals now that the full knowledge of them has been lost (at least most of them), there's no way to properly practice paganism as pagans understood it. Also a lot of neo-pagans haven't even TRIED to really practice historical paganism drawing from what historical sources we do have, but chose instead to make most or all of it up entirely. They were doing this 100 years ago with people like Guido von List and they continued doing it all the way up until now. If you think all religions are made up that's fine, but to me anyway older religions seem much more developed and believable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14488919
>Why can’t a new pagan religion be made?

Neo-Pagan groups typically form in protest against institutions (usually religious ones at that) and a *true* honest to god religious movement can only succeed if it seeks to become an institution itself. An entity that formally establishes and cements itself as an aspect and part of society and not something kicking it's heels in the fucking corner of the house party all alone. A religious movement needs a body of theological work (philosophy, mythology, ritual), but it also needs political momentum, a basic business model, and a means to punish and reward people even if that's just via social means.

People feel less and less of their moral, spiritual, and ethical principles being represented by Chrisianity so the public desire for a "new pagan religion" is absolutely there but it's yet to be capitalized on.
With that said: >>14488925 This Anon isn't even wrong. The development of divergent folk religion and national cultural institutions has really been compromised and outcompeted by the spectacle of consooooomerism, the false promise of "ethical brands", climate change activism, and political arm-chair tomfoolery. All these things in some way or another essentially fill the peg-hole in a person's brain left behind by religion in some way or another.

All of the major subclades of r1b P312 (r-u152, r-L21 and r-df27) most likely originated west of the Rhine somewhere north of the alps, these subclades were then spread by speakers of the Italo-Celtic languages from Sicily to Ireland. Because of the founder effect, elite recruitment, and the general small size of the indoeuropean settlers compared to previous farmer groups (except in the British isles where few farmers survived indo European settlement, though these settlers were most likely also few in number and closely related) some haplogroups became dominant over others. This is also due to genetic drift and bottlenecks both prehistorical and historical (I.e war and plagues). While some areas may have prevalence of some of these classes, they are more or less mixed all across western and Southern Europe as the clades themselves are closely related and were carried by the speakers of the same (or closely related) languages.

>>14481348
Should be noted this is not how cavalry charges worked. If the block of infantry was proper, the horses would collide into the men and be killed from force and the rider would be ejected from inertia and thrown into the block of men. It's a surefire way to kill your horse and probably yourself. Cavalry charges were dependent on the infantry breaking, this is why they wheeled back so much, because if the infantry didn't break the riders would be killed on contact the the infantry wouldn't really suffer all that much.

The video basically shows exactly what not to do. There wasn't enough people and they all broke before contact, which is why they were just run over. Had there been enough people for a proper formation and they were disciplined, the horses likely would have been killed.

>>14477721
Reading through these "battles" it's pretty much always hundreds of Chinese ships and tens of thousands of Chinese soldiers versus like... 6 European ships at most, with most of the European "combatants" being sailors rather than soldiers. The "Dutch fleet" was actually a Dutch trading company, and the "Portuguese fleet" was actually a diplomatic envoy sent to establish a trading post at Guangzhou, and was not even armed with any heavy cannon because they weren't expecting to be ambushed by an army 50x their size when they arrived. Even then they lost only 2 of their 6 ships and less than 50 sailors before managing to escape. Ming China proclaimed this a great victory over the mostly unarmed traders of Portugal, hence dubbed "the barbarian fleet".

Even funnier is that pretty much all of these naval battles were situations where the Chinese attacked Europeans without warning then claimed victory after vanquishing an enemy with a fraction of their own number. Only Russia was different, because it was a case of China and Russia squabbling over control of a region that was on both their borders. Russia scouted it and established a fort, then China attacked the fort several times to force the Russian expedition to leave. I'll give the Chinese credit for this, they "only" outnumbered the Russians 3000 to 2000, a landmark in Chinese-western conflict, though it came at the cost of several hundred Chinese soldiers' lives since they did not outnumber the enemy 10-1 as normal.

It's a ship perfectly designed to defend the coastline and inlets of a peninsula besieged by a foreign invader from the sea. So for Europe, I think it could've probably changed the course of history for any of a few different island nations. Syracuse, for example, might've been able to hold the Romans off indefinitely with these ships, but with gunpowder in the mix, and the Roman propensity for adaptation, I wouldn't bet against team Roma.

>The lorcha is a type of sailing vessel having a junk rig with a Cantonese or other Chinese-style batten sails on a Portuguese or other European-style hull. The hull structure made the lorcha faster and able to carry more cargo than the normal junk. The advantage of the junk rig was in its ease of handling and resulting reduced crewing requirement, together with its relatively low cost of construction. Owing to its simplicity, it was also easier to repair. Lorchas were made locally of camphor or teak and generally were of 30 to 150 tons burthen.


https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hongyipao#Chinese_improvements

>Chinese gunsmiths continued to modify "red barbarian" cannons after they entered the Ming arsenal, and eventually improved upon them by applying native casting techniques to their design. In 1642, Ming foundries merged their own casting technology with European cannon designs to create a distinctive cannon known as the "Dingliao grand general." Through combining the advanced cast-iron technique of southern China and the iron-bronze composite barrels invented in northern China, the Dingliao grand general cannons exemplified the best of both iron and bronze cannon designs. Unlike traditional iron and bronze cannons, the Dingliao grand general's inner barrel was made of iron, while the exterior of brass.[1][12]

>The first form of crucible steel was wootz, developed in India some time around 300 BCE. In its production the iron was mixed with glass and then slowly heated and then cooled. Thoughts on Reform Judaism?

They believe the Jewish people are an ever evolving ethno-religious civilization.

They profess belief in a personal theistic and transcendent God whom they believe to be an indivisible unity.

They believe in progressive revelation, and consider the Hebrew Bible inspired scripture, but reject its literal interpretation and don't believe Moses literally wrote the Torah.

They study the Talmud but do not consider the legal opinions of the Rabbis as binding. Instead they say halakha is an ever evolving system of jurisprudence that should take into account the innovations of modern society. They leave interpretation and application of Jewish Law up to individual believers, which may even include abandoning circumcision or kosher laws, and instead emphasize the social justice of the Hebrew prophets and prayer as more important for a Jew's spiritual life rather than halakha. They ordain women and lgbtqia+ to the Rabbinate, officiate same sex marriage ceremonies, allow for abortion, reject traditional gender roles, and generally advocate for liberal political policy.

They reject any belief in a personal Jewish Messiah or a future Messianic age, declaring the people of Israel as a collective to be the light of monotheism to the gentiles instead. They do not advocate for the construction of a Third Temple, a reinstitution of the Aaronic priesthood and sacrifice, and reject any future resurrection of the dead or afterlife of any kind. Reform Judaism is anti-eschatology. Instead they understand the modern synagogue as the new spiritual Temple for the Jewish people to worship in.

Reform Judaism is the largest form of Judaism in the United States and the second largest form of Judaism in the world after Orthodox Judaism.

Thoughts?

Thor is the ideal of what a norsemen was supposed to be like. Odin conversely will have his redemption at ragnarok when he faces his fate and dies heroically, like Thor.
There may, in the end, be no pre-germanic roots for the character of Odin, he might simply be a product of the germanic mind and their culture and way of life.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Ending the Vietnam conflict had been one of Nixon's campaign pledges. He had not started the war, but he made it a promise that he would end it. Peace would be harder than the president had supposed it would, however. Now retired French president De Gaulle advised a go-slow policy and to include North Vietnam at the negotiating table. Nixon remarked privately that he wasn't going to be the first American president to lose a war, and defeat in Indochina would be terrible for morale at home and America's international image.

Nixon perhaps innocuously thought peace could be achieved in time for the 1970 midterm elections. Hanoi didn't concern themselves with election cycles, or indeed anything short of total victory and the reunification of Vietnam under the DRV. Attempts to extend peace feelers to them met with no response. In February 1969, a few weeks into the new administration, a renewed NVA offensive was launched. Nixon decided to retaliate by bombing NVA sanctuaries in Cambodia, but however strategically necessary it was, it was bad optics when considered against his "end the war" campaign pledge. As such, Nixon made sure to not publicize the bombings, indeed the Air Force was not to even mention it in their official records.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Next, the president proposed withdrawing 25,000 US troops from South Vietnam in exchange for Hanoi also removing any troops from there, internationally supervised elections, and a cessation of hostilities. Since Nixon got no official response from the DRV, he sent a personal appeal to Ho Chi Minh followed by a secret meeting between Secretary of State Kissinger and North Vietnamese foreign minister Mai Van Boi in Paris. These talks went nowhere since Hanoi did not officially admit the presence of any NVA troops in the South, and Ho's reply back to Nixon amounted to a "go to Hell" response. Hanoi would accept nothing short of total withdrawal of all US military personnel from the South and the removal of its president Thieu.

It had become clear that North Vietnam was counting on pressure from antiwar activists. Premier Pham Van Dong called on "progressive people in the US to struggle against the US imperialists" in a planned wave of antiwar demonstrations scheduled for October 15 in several US cities. The protests were vast in size; 250,000 persons in Washington DC, 100,000 in Boston, and 100,000 in San Francisco. Furthermore, these protesters were heavily comprised of solid middle-aged, middle-class professionals, hardly dope-smoking long hairs or leftist bomb throwers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Nixon was only momentarily rattled when a British military expert, Sir Robert Thompson, visited the White House with advice. Thompson was familiar with insurgencies and jungle warfare from the 1950s Malaysia insurgency, and he proposed that a low cost, long haul plan could force Hanoi back. This was the genesis of what became Vietnamization. Nixon himself did not know the ground situation in Vietnam that well, but he well grasped the strategic and geopolitical implications of allowing South Vietnam to be defeated and how it would impact Soviet and Chinese views on America and American strength or weakness.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In a nationally televised address November 3, Nixon explained that the US would stand by and bulk up Saigon's defenses to the point where it would be self-sustaining. He stressed that to allow South vietnam to fall would be a "grievous" defeat for US prestige abroad and embolden the march of global communism, and that US troop withdrawals would proceed as the South Vietnamese were built up to handle their own national security. He closed with the following words:

"And so tonight, to you the great silent majority of my fellow Americans, I ask for your support. I pledged in my campaign for the presidency to end the war in a way that we could win the peace. I have initiated a plan of action which will enable me to keep that pledge. The more support I can have from the American people, the sooner that the pledge can be redeemed, for the more divided we are at home the less likely the enemy is to negotiate in Paris. Let us be united for peace. Let us also be united against defeat. Because, let us understand: North Vietnam cannot defeat or humiliate the United States. Only Americans can do that."

No. I don't know how to put this otherwise but it was over by 1966. The colonial era government was simply too artificial and paralyzed to actually do anything other than wait for the conflict and bomb their way to victory. For Rhodesia to have *any* serious future, it would have had to remain a British Colony. In such a case the central government in Salisbury would take direct orders from the UK, especially in regards to black rights. The government would have had to negotiate a situation where blacks could obtain equal rights easily and set up literacy programs, preferably through British taxpayer money. In exchange the RAF get an airbase to park missiles and bombers at, which isn't a lot but is not zero. White Rhodesians would have to accept much higher taxes and officially, formally agree to subsidize black development. The entire government would be set up to make the black population capable of political participation, as was the case (sort of) in nearby RSA. In such a case Rhodesia would remain a very poor, very shit country with all the wealth located around the RAF airbase/launchpad in the capital but it would still exist. Blacks would make a larger share of the electorate and the government over the latter 20th century, with majority rule happening around 1980. Under what circumstances who knows, but it would happen. How RSA would handle it is anyone's guess. Today it would be comparable to nearby Zambia or perhaps French Guinea, unremarkable but poor except for some sort of big western-subsidized science lab setup there.

Rhodesia was never going to last long as an independent country, and independence was the stupidest decision the white government could have chosen. It was done because they wanted all the benefits of having a white society without any of the larger commitments to a larger white empire that they were a part of. That was their undoing and is why Zimbabwe is a failed state.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For the record Chinese influence was able to spread because they built railways. The Rhodesian government refused to finance their own industrialization and imported most of their locomotives from the UK, and used narrow-gauge track as nearby RSA did. China sent entire machine shops, industrial plants and standard-gauge track with modern diesels. This is still a form of colonialism, but goes to show how utterly inane the Rhodesian policy was. They seriously thought they could be Ford's Africa Factory, when RSA did it better. Or at least retain access to Ford-RSA at favorable prices so they didn't have to industrialize. Ford pulled out of Africa and RSA as a whole in the 60s, which greatly hurt Rhodesian transportation capability. They did build their own IFVs and transport trucks but not in the numbers required to win a war. Which says everything that needs to be said about the war: they were outflanked by a numerically superior enemy with a superior industrial capacity, even if it was managed badly and haphazardly the communists simply had more material available to them.

This didn't work out long term due to corruption and China becoming less aggressive in the 70s/80s, but we're talking about Rhodesia not Zimbabwe here. RSA took notes from this and is how they held out so long, without rail electrification (and electric coal trucks too) RSA would have folded in the 70s. Americans opposing trains are stupid in this regard, the most racist society ever bought itself two decades simply by using trains and it's how the post-aparthied SA economy has been able to handle itself without *really* collapsing as Zimbabwe's did.
